titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. V:30. Friday. I have much inconvenience in writing when at Boston; but rise with the first day-light, and this Morning wrote till breakfast time; which is between seven and eight O’Clock. After breakfast, I called, at the U.S. Branch Bank, the State Bank; and the Mutual Fire Insurance Company; where I took minutes of the payments on the former renewals of my policies, and made proposals for insurance of my houses in Court Street and Hancock Street— I met Mr John Parker, who shewed me a Letter from Baltimore, containing a statement of the Indictments pending there for Bank swindling, to the amount of three Millions of Dollars— Between eleven and twelve O’Clock, I went with my wife, to the chamber of our Sons George and John at Cambridge. They have the same chamber that George and Motte had last year— I told John what I proposed to do with the medal and chain given him by his Grandfather— Which is to keep the medal as a memorial of the giver, and to send the chain to the Mint, and have its proceeds vested in Stocks yielding interest, till he shall come of age: with this arrangement, John said he should be satisfied— We paid a wedding visit to Dr. Waterhouse, who was married last week to Miss Louisa Lee; a Lady of apparently forty-five— We also visited at Mr Timothy Fuller’s; living at Cambridge-port— He is the member of Congress from the Middlesex District— He was confined to his bed by illness; but we saw Mrs Fuller. I left the mortgage of my brother’s Medford Place with the Register of Deeds Mr Bartlett, to be recorded— We returned to Boston, and dined at Mrs Welsh’s— Her son Thomas also dined
there. As we sat down to dinner, I was called out by Mr Jacob Eustis, the Doctor’s brother, who had been in search of me all the Morning, and who came to ask me to enquire at Washington, why his Accounts, as Commissary of Supplies during the late War, were not settled. He said he would detain me only a moment, but kept me a full half-hour, talking of every thing, flying from subject to subject without connection or transition, and speaking in broken sentences, which he never gave himself time to finish— After dinner Mr Hinckley came in— He has also been in search of me these ten days— He had a Letter from the ex-consul O’Brien, with whom he says he was a fellow prisoner at Tripoli. O’Brien had desired him to make some enquiry of me concerning his claims. I told him as I had often told O’Brien himself that Congress alone could allow them. It seems that Hinckley has similar claims of his own; but he said nothing to me about them— I went to the Athenaeum, and until dark examined the Journals of Congress, to complete the Supplement for the publication of the Convention Journals. In the Evening I passed an hour at Dr Parkman’s, and returned for Mrs Adams at Dr Welsh’s— There was a thunder shower this Evening.

2. V:30. I called this morning upon Mr Edward Cruft, who gave me a statement of his account with me as my Agent: and from whom I also took to copy, a minute of cases and boxes of Books which I brought with me from England; and which are now deposited in a warehouse of Mr Thorndike. Great part of the Morning I was at the Athenaeum, examining the Journals of Congress, in preparation for Wait’s publication of the Convention Journals. Jos. Hall, and General Sumner came and took me to see a printing Press, newly invented by a Mr Treadwell; which is a great improvement upon the ordinary presses, and upon that patented to Mr Clymer of Philadelphia, but differing entirely from the invention of König— As the Press was not this day at work, I am to see it again next Wednesday— With General Sumner, I inspected at Wait’s an ordinary printing Press and at the Centinel Office one of Clymer’s; upon the view of which Treadwell’s appeared manifestly an improvement upon them— My Sons John and George came into town and they, with my wife, our Son Charles and myself dined with Mr Hall— After dinner, George and John returned to Cambridge— The rest of us in the Evening came out to my father’s house at Quincy.

3. IV: I rise an hour before day-break; yet find more occupation than time to suffice for it. The nights and mornings too have become so cold, that I find it almost impracticable to write without a fire. It being communion day Mr Whitney preached at home, and I attended morning and afternoon. Three children were baptized; one of them a daughter of Luther Spear’s; by the name of Abigail Adams, which being that of my Mother, and being to me quite unexpectedly given out affected me more than I could have imagined. Mr Whitney’s discourses were not very impressive, and left few traces upon my memory— Mr Quincy, with his eldest daughter Susan, and Mr Marston, with his Sister and daughter spent part of the Evening here. I was engaged at the Office, with Mr Glover, Mr Henry Hardwick, and my brother, in consultation, for the building of a Barn, at the Mount Wollaston Farm— The lumber for it has been bespoken already; but the time and mode of completing it are objects of consideration— I become daily more and more aware of the necessity which is approaching for me, to provide for myself some permanent employment, to be substituted for the public duties which now absorb my time. Some employment which may engage my feelings, and excite a constant interest; leaving as few hours as possible for listlessness, repining or discontented broodings. Farming may perhaps answer the purpose; but my ignorance of it, and of every thing connected with it will prove a great, if not an insuperable obstacle to my success in this plan— Meanwhile I must leave all such things to be managed by others; my brother in particular, with the advice of my father and of Mr Quincy— It will be impossible for me to give attention to it after my return to Washington.

4. V:15. I had devoted this Morning to visiting my woodlots on my old Penn’s Hill farm; and started with my brother, at eight O’Clock immediately after breakfast— We crossed the Hill, called Mount Ararat, and beyond it met Mr Josiah French who then went with us. We visited the three woodlots numbered 3. 5. and 6 in
my father’s deed to me of 8. August 1803. French pointed out to me the boundaries of them, which have never been well known to myself. I marked a couple of trees with an A for remembrance hereafter. There were on the lot N. 3, twelve trees, cedar and hemlock, each from 30 to 40 feet long, which had been cut down, and drawn together after the gale of September 1816, and have been lying there ever since— French and my brother think they will be good for timber to build the Barn; and if upon advisement with Glover this shall be found so, French is to draw out the trees and take them down to the farm, as soon as the winter sledding shall come on. We returned by the way of my Rocky-run and Atherton’s pasture, after a walk of nearly five hours. Immediately after dinner we attended the examination of the children at the Quincy Grammar School; which is kept by Mr Sever. There were fifty two boys, and forty-nine girls—the examination was in reading, writing, grammar, arithmetic and Geography, and it was a very good exhibition of the kind— The children were all decently dressed; under good discipline; and answered as well upon the examination, as I have ever heard upon any similar occasion— Mr Sever the teacher had promised two prizes for the best specimens of writing by the girls— The School-committee were to decide upon inspection to whom the prizes should be given. They found six of the copies so nearly equal in merit, that they declined pronouncing between them; but decided that lots should be drawn for the prizes, by the six— The first prize fell by the lots, which were prepared by Mr Sever, and drawn by the girls themselves, to a daughter of Joseph Field, and the second to my brother’s daughter Abigail— Mr Whitney as Chairman of the School-committee, made a short complimentary address to the children, on the satisfactory manner in which they had passed through the examination— Mr Marston was at my father’s house, this Evening, and renewed a solicitation, which he had made more than once before, for an appointment to some office. I could wish, but have not the means to gratify him— I wrote this Morning to Mr Daniel Brent, and enclosed to him all the despatches and Letters, belonging to the Department, which I have received since my last Letter to him.

5. IV:30. Boston. We had fixed upon this day, to take leave at my father’s house in Quincy, and come to Boston, preparatory to our departure on our return to Washington— The circumstances of my private affairs, have so greatly changed since I made my Will on the 27th of July 1809. and particularly since I have now been here that it became in my own opinion indispensable to cancel that Will; and quite advisable to make another— But I have had so little controul of my time here that until this day, I had been able only to begin the draught of it, which I completed this Morning. I then made out a fair copy of it, ready to be signed sealed and witnessed; which occupied all the leisure of the day. It was still done in haste, and some important dispositions which occurred to me after the draft was finished, and which I inserted into the copy, led me to the reflection, that a Will should be made at a time of leisure; and with full deliberation; and especially that it should not be deferred to a death-bed— The thought which I had suggested to my father, and which he did not approve seemed however to me so proper for my own use that I resolved to prepare a schedule of all my property to be filed with my Will, and serve as an immediate and full indication of it to my Executors, in case my decease should be sudden— But I had not time to prepare the schedule this day. As one reflection naturally leads to another, some further precautions suggested themselves to me as proper for every person possessing a considerable Estate; and having a family to whom it should pass, after his death.— By the blessing of divine Providence, for which my heart can never be sufficiently grateful, my condition is now affluent; but my property is much scattered; much of it is very precarious and fluctuating; and it is burthened with a heavy debt. It will require steady attention and cool judgment, to be advantageously managed; and it should be put into such order as may prepare it for an easy settlement and distribution, when I shall be gone— These remarks have brought to my remembrance, that there is no catalogue of the library, which in 1809. I deposited at the Athenaeum; and no inventory of the household furniture that I have at Washington— Mr Shaw promised to have a complete Catalogue of my Books at the Athenaeum made out, but it never has been done— These are deficiencies which I must take care to have supplied— Mr J. M. Forbes and W. Tudor came this Morning and visited me at Quincy— About five this Afternoon we took leave of my father, my brother and his family; and with my wife, and my son Charles I came into Boston. Charles went to Dr Welsh’s; Mrs Adams and I to Mrs Burr’s; where we passed the remainder of the Evening in our chamber; and having at length a table, I could write a Letter.

6. IV:15. I wrote this morning an answer to a Letter received a few days since, from Joseph Lancaster, upon the subject of his method of instruction, and of a project that he has for opening one of his Schools in Boston; which I earnestly wish may succeed— Lancaster was at Washington last Winter, and gave two or three Lectures there, which I
accidentally missed hearing— Since I have been here, he went out to my father’s house to thank him, for a Letter in his favour, which my father wrote, and which has been published; and with the expectation of seeing me, there; but I was that day in Boston— I was also to have met him at Dr Ingalls’s; but was obliged to send an excuse for that party— He has now written to solicit my aid in the promotion of his plan; which I would cheerfully give, as far as I possess the means— Dr Parkman called upon me; and gave some information respecting the recent appointment of the Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory at the University at Cambridge— Mrs Adams went to Cambridge to take leave of our Sons, George and John: she returned to Boston to dinner, and brought me the deed that I had left with the Register of Deeds to be recorded. I went with General Sumner, and saw again Treadwell’s printing Press; it was at work, and confirmed me in the opinion of its superiority to the ordinary presses and even to Clymer’s that I had formed last Saturday— Judge Davis and President Kirkland were there— At Wait’s I revised two or three proof-sheets of the Convention Journals, and gave him the minutes I had drafted for the Supplement. I called at the Mutual Fire Insurance Office, and agreed to take the two Policies on my houses in Court Street, and Hancock Street, on the terms proposed by the Company— At the State Bank I took the Certificate of Stock, 5. Shares, which had been transferred to me last week by my brother— Dined at our lodgings, the only time since I have been in Boston; immediately after dinner, Degrand came, and kept me about two hours, in conversation, chiefly upon his own Affairs. He wants an appointment as Consul at some Port in France. Mrs Humphreys had sent me by Artiguenave a Message requesting me to call upon her, which I did this afternoon. Her object was to speak with me concerning the Establishment at Humphreysville, near New-Haven, Connecticut; and extensive Woollen Manufacture, upon which her late husband General Humphreys expended much money, and made as she says heavy losses— He had connected with it; large farms of Merino Sheep; a village, and a school for the children who worked at the manufactory— It was a project upon a large scale; mingling purposes of benevolence, of patriotism, and of speculation for profit— But according to Yorick’s sarcastic remark upon the French character, it was better conceived than combined. Plans so gigantic and complicated, are not suited to the simplicity and mediocrity of Fortune prevailing in this Country. While the late War lasted the manufacture might thrive sufficiently to defray its own expences, but when Peace came, Humphreysville soon became a burden to its owner, which no one person could, and no company would take from his shoulders— Mrs Humphreys put into my hands several drafts or copies of Letters found among his papers after his decease; from their contents they appear to have been addressed to Mr Monroe, between the time of his election and inauguration as President of the U.S. and to another person, a member of Congress, about the same time— They proposed that the Government of the United States should purchase the whole Establishment of Humphreysville, which they represent to be excellently well suited for a military school or academy. This is also now the object of Mrs Humphreys, who has been obliged to stop entirely the work at the manufactory, and to whom the whole establishment is a mere dead weight of expence, with the exception of a grist-mill and a paper-mill, which yet work— I took the papers with me and perused them; and soon came to the conclusion that this was one of the cases almost numberless, in which I can only regret my inability to render any essential service— In the Evening I called, first at Mr Cruft’s and afterwards at Mr James H. Foster’s— Mrs W. Smith, mother, Mrs D. Pickman, sister, and Thomas Smith, brother of Mrs Cruft were there, and went to the Circus— While I was at Foster’s there was a cry of fire; he immediately went out with me in search of it— We soon found it was at the rope-walk belonging to Winslow Lewis, at the bottom of the Common— The whole building, near 600 feet long was burnt down— Although erected on the Marsh, the tide being out there was no water to be had— There was little wind; but the fire itself, and the smoke of the burning tar created a draft, which raised and floated burning coals entirely across the Common— One of them as big as a pigeons egg fell close at our feet on the Common, and near its upper end— Foster went off to take care of his Store in Marlborough Street, which he thought was in danger, and I
went to the fire. There was a great crowd of people, and several Engines, but only one pump from which Water could be drawn. There were three other Ropewalks, close by the side of one another; but the wind blowing from them they were all saved; with some damage to the one next the fire. I met John Welsh there, and after waiting some time, and perceiving that we could render no service, I went with him to his father’s house. Mrs Adams was there— And Mrs Bailey, Dr Welsh’s eldest daughter, with her child—from Wiscasset where she resides— My son John soon came in— He was from Cambridge, and had come with the Fire-Engine from the College— He soon left us to attend his engine— Returning home, I sat with Mr Burr, who has just returned from Machias where he has been preaching, and conversed with him, and two of my name-sakes and fellow-boarders, upon Trinity and Unity, until one in the Morning, when the Fire, though still burning, was nearly extinct, and I retired to bed.

7. VI: I had intended to leave Boston this Morning to return to Washington; but the hours of departure of the Stages have been changed since the last year; so that I concluded to take the Stage for Providence on Saturday Morning— My wife therefore went out to Quincy with Charles, and spent this day at my Father’s— My brother and his wife came to town; and he went to Medford— I called this morning upon Joseph Hall, the Sheriff, Edward Cruft and James H. Foster and requested them to meet me at the Athenaeum at one O’Clock to Witness the signing and publishing of my Will, which they did— I read it to them, before signing it; and they all subscribed it as witnesses— I went and dined with Cruft, and returned after dinner to the Athenaeum. But the heat was that of high midsummer; and so overpowering that I could neither write nor read. I examined the books in the chambers where mine are kept, and found numbers of very valuable books damaged, and others missing, of which Mr Hill, the young man who attends as Librarian could give no account— He promised me however to make out a complete Catalogue of those that are left. My wife returned from Quincy, and we spent the Evening at Dr Welsh’s. The Doctor himself was at home. Mrs. S. A. Otis and her two daughters, and Mrs Hinckley were there— I made this Morning a partial settlement of account with Mr Cruft.

8. IV:15. A person by the name of Eayres came to me yesterday and again this morning, to request the interposition of the Government to obtain the liberation of his Son, who is a prisoner in some of the Spanish dominions in South-America, where he has been these six or seven years confined. The father had two Letters from him which he brought me; one dated in 1814 and the other in 1817. but they did not expressly state that he was a prisoner; nor even distinctly where he was. I took a written minute of his case, to be remembered on my return to Washington. A Mr Blanchard came with a very affecting complaint of his poverty and distress; to remedy which he began by asking for an office, and concluded with asking for a dollar. Mr Robert Hewes, sometime fencing master and butcher, and always a bone-setter came to inform me of his extraordinary talents in this last capacity. Shubael Hewes, whom I knew as a famous bone-setter, and who actually did set my Son George’s shoulder when it was dislocated in 1808 Robert says was his uncle or cousin, and learnt from him all that he knew. It is a family faculty, and Robert says, a secret which will perish with him, unless he should publish it in a book, with plates, which would discover it to all the world. He came to propose that the Government of the United States should buy his secret of him; and also, if I should fall in with Governor Clinton at New-York, who met with an accident last year, and broke or dislocated his knee-pan I should tell him that Robert Hewes of Boston could make him whole. These visitors, detained me at home until noon, when I went with Charles and bathed, at the floating Sea water baths by the side of Craigie’s Bridge—thence to the Athenaeum to pack up a chest of Books and other Articles to send to Washington— At one, I went with Joseph Hall, and General Sumner, and dined with Governor Brooks at Medford. There was no other Company— Soon after dinner Hall and Sumner left the table, to go and pay a visit to Mr Bigelow, the Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth. The Governor, when we were left tete a tete, began by asking my opinion with regard to the separation
of the District of Maine from the State; I gave it to him without reserve: that it was an event much to be lamented, as affecting the importance of the State as a member of the Union; but quite unavoidable from the moment that it became the wish of a majority of the People in the District. Massachusetts has been hitherto in point of population and wealth one of the first States in the Union— It will henceforth scarcely be the tenth— The additional weight of two votes in the Senate of the United States is a very inadequate compensation for this loss of comparative importance— It appears to be the general opinion here, that this event will render necessary a Convention to revise the Constitution of Massachusetts— The Governor did not dwell much upon this topic; but passed very soon to a claim of this State upon the Union, for a million or twelve hundred thousand dollars expended during the late war, in defensive measures by the Militia. In the career of opposition to the General Government, which that of Massachusetts then pursued they refused to place the Militia under the command of an Officer of the United States; upon a Construction of the Constitution of the United States, by the judges of the Supreme Judicial Court of the Commonwealth, for which nothing but the depraving and stupefying influence of faction can account— The immediate consequence of which was that the expence as well as the command fell upon the State— And now, after the war is over, the State calls upon the Union to defray the charge, which has of course hitherto been declined. The expenditures are of the same kind with those which have been paid by the Union in all the other States; even in Connecticut, a State the temper and conduct of which during the War, were quite as refractory against the General Government, as those of Massachusetts, but which when called upon to place the Militia, under the command of an Officer of the United States was too wary to incur the consequences of a refusal and complied— The federal party by which the opposition to that of the Union was managed have lost the controul of Connecticut and of all the other New-England States, but still retain their ascendancy in Massachusetts. They are now claiming to be refunded the expenses, which in the wantonness of their pride and obstinacy they assumed upon themselves, and with their usual political discernment they expect to obtain it, without disavowing the defiance of the Union, which released them from all obligation to bear the burthen— I told Governor Brooks, that as a native of Massachusetts, it would give me the greatest pleasure to serve the State, and I would on my return to Washington consult the President, to ascertain if any satisfactory arrangement of this affair could be made— But it must ultimately depend upon Congress; and the difficulty there would be that the Union cannot assume those expenses, without sanctioning the principle of it own dissolution; involved in the opinion of the Supreme Court of Massachusetts, upon which the State acted. The Governor gave me to understand that he had always disapproved that opinion of the Supreme Court— That there had been almost a misunderstanding upon the subject between him and the late Governor Strong, who was entirely swayed by the then Chief Justice Parsons; the identical man whom the State of Massachusetts has to thank for being in this trouble. He was an eminent lawyer; a man of extraordinary intellectual powers—of deep research and extensive learning; of brilliant and ever ready, though coarse and vulgar wit; and in his domestic and private relations amiable, benevolent and upright— But he was a cunning man. His wisdom was left handed— He was not only addicted to finessing and trick, but he had the weakness to be vain of his artifices, and was always telling of the persons whom he had duped, and sometimes boasting of it in cases when he had in reality been duped himself— The pride of his heart was to overreach: and in this as in many other instances less important, he overreached himself. He was withal a timid man; ready enough to push others into danger, but easily frightened to shrink from it himself— In this very case, after leading the Commonwealth into this quagmire, before his death he disavowed the opinion, which had involved the State in this contest, and acknowledged that it was erroneous— Brooks says, that practically the opinion was very soon done away; and by means of a general order which he insisted upon Strong’s issuing; but I know not exactly what he means. The Militia were not placed under the command of Officers of the United States; the Legislature of the State have never disavowed the principle, of Governor Strong’s refusal to comply with the requisition from the Secretary of War to that effect; and when Resolutions importing such a disavowal were introduced last Winter into the Senate
of the State they were rejected, and all the principles of resistance to the General Government were reasserted with as much ardour and stubbornness as if the War were yet raging. In this state of things; it is waste of time and of temper for the State of Massachusetts to apply to have that money refunded— When Hall and Sumner returned from the Speaker’s we came back to Boston— Mr and Mrs Hall, Degrand, and Dr Parkman afterwards came and took leave of us; and a Mr Everts came to speak of two persons who are going shortly as Missionaries to Palestine; for whom Letters or certificates of recommendations are desired.

9. IV:30. Providence. I sent back Mrs Humphreys’s papers, and this Morning returned those of Mr William Foster; which were accumulating till within half an hour before I left Boston this Morning; when he sent me a new Essay for the Newspapers, and a new request for my opinion, of it, and a volume of others which he has sent me during my visit at Boston. I called at Wait’s and several other places where something had been left to be finished, and at nine O’Clock with my wife and my Son Charles departed from Boston in the Stage to Providence. We took up in Boston four other Passengers; Mr John Gray, son of William Gray; Mr Goodhue of New-York; son of the late Benjamin Goodhue of Salem; a Mr Ward; and a fourth, a Stranger, who parted from us at Providence. I stopped at Dedham, and left at the Office of the Register of Deeds to be recorded, my father’s Deed of the Mount Wollaston Farm, and his Quit-claim of the Verchild pasture; and my brother’s Mortgage of his Estate at Braintree. I was told Mr Rufus King had passed through Dedham last Evening, and gone without entering Boston, directly to Mr Gore’s at Waltham. We dined at Walpole; and in the afternoon between there and Providence, met a Stage in which were Edward Everett and Theodore Lyman, returning from Europe— They arrived, the day before yesterday at New-York from Liverpool— At Providence we found Chappotin’s house full; and were obliged to take our lodgings at a boarding-house next door to it, a Mr M’Clannan’s. Mr Burrell, member of the Senate of the United States came in, and spent the Evening with us.

10. V:— New-London. With Mr Gray, Mr Goodhue and Mr Ward, we took a Stage at Providence, and started at seven this Morning, with a violent South-East Storm of rain; which continued about three hours. We breakfasted at Scituate; being the first Stage; 15 Miles from Providence; and without stopping to dine came through Plainfield and Norwich to New-London where we arrived just at six in the Evening— The Steam-boats, which in the Summer Season go up the river Thames to Norwich, since the first of this Month have proceeded no farther than New-London— The Storm subsided this Morning about ten—the weather cleared away, and the Evening was fine and cold— We lodge at a new house kept by Shepherd— Mr Henry Channing came in and spent part of the Evening with us— At Norwich we overtook Joseph Lancaster, who was coming on to New-London.

11. V:My wife was very ill for a couple of hours this morning; but recovered so as to be able to proceed on our Voyage— We embarked in the Steam-Boat Fulton, Captain Law, and left New-London, precisely at eight O’Clock— Mr Henry Channing came on board to take leave of us, and introduced to me Captain Lee of the revenue Cutter. The day was one of the autumnal beauties of this climate; clear Sunshine; but cool; and with a brisk breeze. Joseph Lancaster, who was on board soon introduced himself to me; and I had much conversation with him upon his system of Instruction. As I had never heard his Lectures, and as we had all, leisure on board the Boats, he proposed to deliver two Lectures there one in the Morning and one in the Evening, to those of the passengers who might be disposed to attend; which was readily accepted— He gave the first on board the Fulton before dinner; and the second in the Evening, on board of the Connecticut, Captain Bunker— He was about an hour and a half each time, and gave great satisfaction to his auditory— He is, as far as he has any education, self-educated—gifted with very extraordinary natural powers of eloquence, but so ignorant of the pronunciation of his native language, that he speaks with all the cockney vulgarities, of the labours in which he is involved; of the harmies of enemies with whom he has to contend, and of the works of his ands. There is too much of the jobber and speculator, in his zeal for the propagation of his system.
There is inordinate vanity and self-conceit in the opinions of himself which he discloses. He is continually thrusting upon you his pretensions to be considered as a benefactor of mankind. His first Lecture contained a development of his system of Instruction, by means of Monitors selected from among the Scholars; and he exhibited several drawings, painted in Water Colours, representing the boys as engaged in their different lessons of reading, writing, and arithmetic, which drawings he said were made by one of his first pupils. He expatiated upon the effects of emulation in children, when judiciously managed; and the uses of extending it from individual to social emulation, by setting two classes in competition with each other— The advantages of arranging the forms of a School so as to accommodate the greatest possible number of Scholars, and keeping them all under the teacher’s eye. The accommodation of the voice to three different keys of low, intermediate and high tone, proportioned to the distances between the Speaker, and the hearer, and the facility of introducing perfect order and discipline, by a few simple rules firmly adhered to, without using the scourge at all. By placing the Monitors alternately in situations of authority and of obedience, he said they had the importance of good discipline brought immediately and practically home to their own feelings. The same boy, who for one hour was a teacher, the next hour became a learner, and was thus taught at once the lesson indispensable to all good discipline; to command, and to obey. The second Lecture contained a historical review of the extent in which the arts of writing and reading in different ages of the world, have been diffused, and of the various systems of instruction which have prevailed— Of the prejudices, passions and interests which have counteracted and are still counteracting the progress of improvement; and of the various inventions and discoveries which have promoted it. He considered the great object to be accomplished was to make the knowledge of reading, writing and the four rules of Arithmetic, universal; and that every new devise tending to facilitate the acquisition of it to greater multitudes of people was a service rendered to the great cause of humanity. His own system he considered as among the most efficacious of those means; and in his second Lecture he alluded to its origin about the year 1797. when he said, he being only eighteen years of age, his father had permitted him to fit up one small chamber of his house as a School-room—and he surveyed with some exultation the interval to this time, when in his fortieth year when he has the satisfaction of knowing that many schools founded upon his system, are in full operation in every quarter of the globe— He would not anticipate the extent to which the progressive development might and he hoped would be carried— It would no doubt be susceptible of improvements many of which would not be discovered till he should be in a better world— His Lectures are desultory and unmethodical, and his historical illustrations, though well applied and ingenious, manifested a very partial knowledge of his subject. His materials are exceedingly scanty, and at every moment you have occasion to regret the penury of his Stores of knowledge, and to see what an admirable use he would make of them if they were more copious— His quaker garb hangs heavy upon him; and nothing but pride and shame deter him from casting it away— There is too much wit and humour in his character for a Quaker. Too much worldliness in his disposition—too much asperity towards his adversaries; and too much suppleness to those whom he thinks or wishes to be his friends— He spoke to me about the rival pretensions of Dr Bell, formerly of Madras, to the invention of his system, and introduced the subject in a way peculiar to himself— Didst thou ever hear, said he, of a Quaker’s bearing Arms?—and without waiting for an answer, took from his pocket and shewed me a Card, on which was drawn a Bell, with the Inscription upon it “Lancaster me fecit”— There, said he, are my arms; and they were given to me, by a friend of mine a Clergyman of the Church of England; and thus an official brother of Dr Bell— I then enquired what had really been the practice of Dr Bell’s school at Madras, and he gave me some account of it; and of Dr Bell himself; who from a Scotch Presbyterian Parson had become a convert to the dignities of the Church of England, and is now a prebendary, under the Bishop of Durham with whom he is in controversy about the payment of a commutation for an ox, or an ox in kind; as rent or tythe upon a living given him by the bishop— He had while chaplain to the East-India Company service, kept a school at
Madras, into which he had introduced a practice of writing upon sand, which was a custom in the Schools of the Country; among the Hindoos; and to supply the place of ushers he had employed some of the larger boys to teach the younger ones, and after Lancaster’s publications had made his system known, had imitated its details— Still he had required the assistance of four ushers for a School of 300 boys, and had never been able to dispense with their services. But being of the established English Church, and teaching the Prayer Book, as well as reading and writing, all the Church Clergymen took up his cause, and would not hear of Joseph Lancaster the Sectarian. Lancaster is now engaged in the attempt to organize by subscription one of his Schools in Boston— But his success is doubtful— We arrived at New-Haven about three in the afternoon; and as we had three hours to wait for the arrival of the Boat from New-York, we took a Carriage with Mr Gray and Mr Goodhue, and rode into the City of New-Haven. We were unsuccessful in our attempts to find at their houses President Day, Professor Silliman, and Mr Hillhouse; nor could we procure a sight of the Yale College Library; but with the aid of one of the Students we did obtain access to the Cabinet of Mineralogy, which belongs not to the College, but to Coll. Gibbs of Newport. There is not much in it worth seeing. We returned about Sunset to our Boat, and half an hour after, the Connecticut Captain Bunker came in— Mr Gracie of New-York was in her, going Eastward— One of our fellow Passengers from New-Haven, was Judge Livingston. We pass the Night in the Steam-Boat.

12. V: Trenton— We arrived this morning just at six O’Clock at New-York, and made an abortive attempt, to proceed immediately in the Post-Chaise line of Stages which would have enabled us to reach Philadelphia this Evening— We were about ten minutes too late for the Stage at that hour, and were obliged to wait for that which departs at eleven O’Clock— We stopped at the City Hotel— After breakfast I called at the houses of Mr Thompson, Secretary of the Navy, and of J. J. Astor, neither of whom was at home. Went also to the Bank of America; to see W. S. Clarkson— He was not there, but immediately afterwards came to us at the City Hotel. W. S. Shaw left it yesterday morning to return to Boston— Mr Hyde de Neuville, the French Minister who is not yet gone to France had called to enquire last Evening, if I had arrived— Jennings, the Master of the House sent him word this morning that I was there; but he was in the Country. At eleven O’Clock we took the Steam Boat Nautilus and without landing at Staten-Island, passed immediately into the Steam-Boat Bellona, in which we came to New-Brunswick— There we landed, and came thence in a Post-Chaise Stage, through Princeton to Trenton, where we arrived about ten in the Evening. The Stage stopped at Voorhees’s; but I came with my family and lodge at Bispham’s; having been very ill used the last year at the other house— There was this Evening a very brilliant Northern light, and a very singular luminous arch passing through the Zenith and extending almost to the two opposite Horizons. We had an affected mincing, but very civil Englishman, two blunt yankeys and a woman for fellow passengers in the Stage.

13. V: Philadelphia— We left Trenton, in the Stage at five O’Clock this Morning, and came to breakfast at Bristol, after which we embarked in the Steam-Boat Pennsylvania, and landed between 11 and 12. O’Clock at Philadelphia. We came immediately to Miss Shinn’s at N. 30. North Third Street— Intending to proceed on our Journey to-morrow, I went immediately to transact my business at the Bank of the United States. I found there Mr Cheves the President, with whom I had much conversation upon the affairs of the Bank and of the Revenue—the situation of which is unpromising. The prospect is of a very large deficiency. I then called upon Israel Whelen, the Treasurer of the Schuylkill Bridge— They made no dividend last January and the Stock is depressed to 70 per Cent— Returned to my lodgings to dinner; my wife and Charles dined in our own chamber. I waited till the Evening to call upon S. Ewing, when I passed an hour with him. I had received at Quincy a Letter from him, requesting me to write an inscription for a monument which he and some of his friends have been erecting to the late Joseph Dennie. I had not answered this Letter; expecting to see Ewing so soon; and having my time so indispensably absorbed that I found it quite impossible then to prepare the Inscription. Ewing shewed me one prepared by W. Meredith in Latin; but said they all preferred that it should be in the vernacular tongue— After returning to my lodgings this Evening
I wrote one; Ewing had persuaded me to pass the day here to-morrow. The phenomenon of the last Evening was followed by a day uncommonly cold for the Season. So cold that on board the Steam Boat from Bristol, the deck was uncomfortable, and most of the Passengers preferred the Cabins— About the middle of the day there was a transient Shower of Snow, and this Evening a sharp Frost.

14. V: Immediately after Breakfast I called upon Ewing, and gave him my draft of an Inscription for Dennie’s Monument. MrCondy and Mr John E. Hall the present Editor of the Port Folio were with Ewing; who was himself so much engaged in attendance upon the Courts now in Session, that he left me with Hall, who accompanied me to the Athenaeum, an establishment similar to, but more recent than the one at Boston— Among the periodical works on the Table, Hall shewed me the last number received of the British Review, containing an Article Upon American Literature, in which is the first notice taken by any foreign Journal, of my Lectures upon Rhetoric— The notice is superficial, and though not flattering, as favourable, as I can ever expect from an English Critic— Hall took me also into an adjoining chamber, where Sully the Painter is engaged upon a large picture of the passage of the Delaware by General Washington, in December 1776. I think it will not be more successful than Trumbull’s picture of the Declaration of Independence— The principal figure is not even a likeness of Washington, and there is no character in the whole composition— The large picture is however as yet barely in chalk— We went into the United States Circuit Court, where Judges Washington and Peters were sitting— Judge Peters came down from the Bench, and spoke to me; and C. J. Ingersoll claimed of me a promise to dine with him— We went into one of the City Courts where Ewing was engaged in a Cause then before the Court. I returned to my lodgings, whither Ingersoll whom I had met on coming out of Court accompanied me, and sat with me perhaps an hour. I then went and paid a visit to Mr Connell whom I found in great dejection and distress— From the tenor of his Conversation when I was here in August I had apprehended that he was embarrassed in his affairs— He now told me that he had been obliged about three weeks since to suspend his payments, and to assign over all his property to his Creditors. The causes of his misfortune were two—an attempt to establish a commercial house, connected with a large land speculation at Blakeley in the State of Alabama; and a purchase of 500 shares of United States Bank Stock at 30 per Cent advance— All his creditors he says will be paid the full amount of their debts, and he determined to stop while he knew this could be effected, rather than resort to ruinous expedients of momentary relief, which would have disabled him in the end to do Justice to all. He was deeply affected in telling me this, and I sympathised heartily with him, convinced as I am of his integrity, industry and frugality— There is no man of whom I have in these respects a more favourable opinion. I endeavoured to encourage him by the hopes of more prosperous times, and lament that it is not in my power to make them certain to him. Before going to dinner I called again upon Ewing, who was just rising from his. He went with me to the Mint, but we found none of its officers there— He then accompanied me to the public City Library, where he left me, being obliged to attend again at the Court— I viewed the Logan Library; a donation from the Grandfather of the present Dr Logan; and the Clock said to have been made for Oliver Cromwell, and to have some time belonged to him— And which is now one of the most accurate time pieces in Philadelphia— Between three and four I went and dined with Ingersoll— Besides his wife the only company present were Levitt Harris and A. M. Dallas. after dinner, Mr Poletica, the Russian Minister, and another Gentleman came in— Poletica said he would call at my lodgings to see me to-morrow Morning— Ingersoll says Poletica makes no friends here, and is neither discreet nor conciliatory in his Conversation— At seven I went again by appointment to Ewing’s, who took me to a tavern in Sixth Street, where we spent the Evening and had a delicious supper. The whole company consisted of John Sergeant—P. Markoe, Mr Condy, Dr Chapman, and Ewing— Meredith was absent, detained by other engagements— I expected that the Inscription for Dennie’s Monument would have been submitted to critical examination, but it was not mentioned— We broke up, between eleven and twelve at Night.

15. V:Mr Poletica came this Morning, according to his appointment; but he had not much to say; and I did not encourage him to talk upon any public business— He asked if I had any late despatches from Europe; but I had none; and was even without information from the Department of State for the last ten days— I went to the Mint, and left there the Chain belonging to my Son John to be coined. One of the Officers shewed me the buildings and the machinery; but the only work that was doing, was by two men who were striking off Cents. The establishment appeared to me to be in no very flourishing condition— I called next on the Brokers M’EwenHale and Davidson, and terminated with them a transaction, upon which I had applied to them yesterday. They took at the United States Bank, my Check on the Branch Bank Boston; and supplied me with the Money for it— At noon we embarked in the Steam-boat Baltimore, Captain Jenkins— Connell came and accompanied us to the Boat, and we found Mr Ecky in it, who told us he was himself coming on, in the Boats to morrow— We reached Newcastle about five in the afternoon; and proceeding immediately in the Post-Chaise arrived between eight and nine at Frenchtown— There we embarked again in the Steam Boat Philadelphia Captain Spencer, in which we are to pass the Night.

16. V. Washington. We arrived at Baltimore between four and five this Morning. I had quietly slept out the whole passage, and was surprized to learn that there had been a heavy swell in the Bay; insomuch that my Son Charles had been up, from between one and two O’Clock— We landed and came to Barnum’s Tavern; the same lately kept by Gadsby and formerly by Evans; where we breakfasted. At seven O’Clock we left Baltimore in the Stage; and at two in the afternoon, arrived all safe and in good health at our own house in Washington. Half an hour after we got in, our arrival was announced in the Washington City Gazette; Mr Daniel Brent came to see us in the afternoon; and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith in the Evening. Mary Hellen who has been living with them during our absence, returned to our house— I took possession of my new writing chamber, and began upon the ever recurring task of redeeming the arrears of this Journal; which have again accumulated from the first of the Month— It is but this day week that we left Boston, and in the interval we have performed without losing one Night’s rest a Journey of five hundred Miles. The Steam-Boats have effected a change in the convenience and expedition of this Journey, the value of which is inestimable— A week, was an ordinary period of time for a passage by the Packets from Providence to New-York; and it was not uncommon to be two Nights out upon Chesapeake Bay between French town and Baltimore. The time too was anxiously passed; depending upon the changes of wind and wave—dreading alike a calm or a storm; and subject to all the vexations and disappointments of a veering weathercock— We have now a single, or a two days ride from Boston to Norwich or New-London at our option— One Night on board the Steam-Boat, upon the passage through Long-Island Sound; a days Journey to Philadelphia, varied by alternate Steam-boat and stage, and one short Night upon Chesapeake Bay— In the Steam-boats, the provisions of the day and the beds for the Night are equal to those of a very good Inn— You meet with a great variety of company with whom you can associate, or from whom you can keep aloof, at your pleasure. You can employ yourself in reading or writing, if so inclined. A rule established in all the boats, and from which I have never witnessed an exception, prohibits all card-playing; this also is a great improvement upon the Packets of former times; where I have known gambling and its filthy appendages smoking and drinking, the whole night long— The behaviour of the passengers in the Steamboats, is almost universally decent— The women have a cabin to themselves; into which no man is admitted— The smoking is banished or confined to the forecastle cabin. The intrusion of dogs is forbidden; and other rules for the preservation of cleanliness, good order and punctual payment are prescribed, by printed notices hung up in the Cabins, and are very generally observed. Religious Tracts and printed Sermons are scattered about the cabins to attract the attention of the idle, and here and there you lay your hand upon a Book, which upon opening it, you find to be a Bible. There is a sort of spasmodic, and tremulous motion in the Boat very disagreeable to
many persons, particularly Ladies; and the noise of the Steam-Engine, of the paddles in the water, and of the Steam, when the valves are opened to let it escape are unpleasant, and sometimes to weak nerves alarming. But these inconveniences are trifling compared to those of any other mode of traveling; and the Steam Boat is to be considered altogether as one of the greatest and most beneficent inventions of modern ages.

17. VI:15. Visits from Joseph Wheaton, Robert Wright, Cardelli, and Messrs.D. Brent, Young, Bailey and Maury, of the Department. Wright told me that he was a Sportsman, and had come here to attend the Washington Races— He was formerly a Member of the Senate of the United States; where I sat with him three or four years— He was then elected Governor of Maryland; but resigned that office before the usual term of three years which the Governors of that State usually serve had expired. He has since been several years a member of the House of Representatives, but did not succeed in his Election for the last or the present Congress. He says he expects to be now returned to the Senate of the United States again, as the member for the Eastern Shore— Both the Seats in the Senate from Maryland are vacant. One by the Death of Mr Hanson; and the other by the expiration of the term of service of Mr Goldsborough— They were both federalists, but the complexion of the Legislature of Maryland being now changed, it is to be expected both the members to be chosen will be of the other party. W. Pinkney and Edward Lloyd have been mentioned in the newspapers; but Wright says neither of them would serve if they were elected, nor be elected if they would serve— Wright must be upwards of seventy years of age, but looks more healthy and vigorous than he did fifteen years ago when a member of the Senate. I took Charles before dinner to Mr Ironsides, but he was not at home. I met in the Street, Mr Thierry, with Mr Picaut, who gave me a Letter from Mr Hyde de Neuville, the French Minister, from whom he came as a special Messenger, and by whom he said he was directed to wait for my answer— I desired him to call at my Office at one O’Clock to-morrow. I paid visits to Mr. Wirt and Mr Crawford. Charles went in with me at Mr Wirt’s. I had some conversation with him concerning a School. He appeared not to have a favourable opinion of Ironside; but recommended a Mr Canahan at Georgetown, who keeps a large School of eighty boys; where his own Son goes. My call upon Mr Crawford was short; being interrupted by other visitors. Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were again here, this Evening.

18. VI:15. Before Breakfast I went out again with Charles, to call at the house of Mr Ironside; but we met him going to his School, which he now keeps in a small apartment adjoining and connected with the Treasury Office. Charles commenced his attendance at the School. Mr Ecky from Philadelphia called upon me, with another person whose name was not mentioned. Ecky said he was going for a day or two into the Country; and on his return would call at my Office with some papers; relating to claims on the Swedish Government— I called at the Bank of the Metropolis, and made the necessary arrangements for the transaction of my business there. I attended at my Office which has been removed to the Southeast corner chamber, in the new Building erected immediately opposite to the Treasury. I was soon overwhelmed as heretofore; with despatches, Letters and Newspapers by the Mails. Young Fenwick soon came in. He is like Horace’sNature. “Naturam expellas furca, tamen usque recurret.” He has been besieging the Department for an Office, ever since I have been in it— He, after many abortive attempts to get into the diplomatic career, finally prevailed upon Forsyth to take him as his private Secretary to Spain— But Forsyth could not fail to discover before he had been a month at Madrid, that a private Secretary was a dead weight of expence, and of no manner of use to an American Minister; and so when the 22d. of August came, and he found an occasion for sending of despatches, he made Fenwick a special messenger to carry them to Bordeaux; and there put them on board of an American Vessel, about to sail for this Country— Arrived at Bordeaux, Mr Fenwick, found it convenient to come with the despatches himself; which he did of his own head, and without commission or authority from Forsyth; and here he is renewing the Siege for Office; and leaving it to me to decide, whether he shall be paid as a special messenger, for bringing without a shadow of authority the despatches from Bordeaux— I told him I should refer it to the President. Mr Frye called at my Office, and he and his wife were
here this Evening. Mr Picaut came according to appointment to my Office at one O’Clock. I told him I would immediately communicate Mr de Neuville’s Letter to the President, and so soon as I should receive his Instructions, which I supposed would be in the course of this week, would answer the Letter by the Mail. He said he should then immediately proceed upon his return to New-York.

19. V:Cardelli was here this morning, and I engaged him to give lessons of Drawing, three times a week, to my Son Charles and Mary Hellen—Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at seven in the Evening— He was to have begun this Evening; but was unwell, and at Night sent me word that he had been obliged to take to his bed. This day the races commenced, and the Public Offices were almost deserted. I called at the Branch Bank, and changed a small Bill, which had been given me with a number of others at the Branch at Boston— It was signed by the Cashier, but not by the President; and from its appearance had circulated through many hands— Its date was of 1. Feby 1817. and should have been signed by William Jones. I was also at the Metropolis Bank upon other business— B. Homans the Chief Clerk of the Navy Department came to ask directions for Instructions to be given to Captain Charles Morris who has been designated to take the place of the gallant, and lamented Captain O. H. Perry, who after performing part of the service which had been assigned to him, by going to Angostura, fell a victim to the climate, and died of the yellow fever in August last at the Island of Trinidad— His business was less than half accomplished, and Morris is to be charged with the remainder of the Commission. Homans sent me a Journal kept by a Mr Handy, who ascended the Oronoco river with Captain Perry, and was with him at Angostura— And the Correspondence which Perry had with Mr Roscio, the Secretary of State of Venezuela. Commodore Decatur was likewise at the Office— He gave me a Letter to him from a Master of a Merchant vessel named Cooper, complaining of having been taken, and plundered by a piratical privateer of Aury’s; and by Aury himself at Old Providence. But Decatur’s principal object was to ask for some allowance, for the benefit of Perry’s widow and Children; to which I think they have the most undoubted of claims.— My wife and the children spent the Evening at W. S. Smith’s; and at the close of it, I called for them there.

20. VI:30. The Races this day made a Holiday at Charles’s School— Mr Ecky came to the Office, and brought a number of papers relating to the claims upon the Swedish Government; for which he was an Agent. Of all the robberies which were committed upon the property of Citizens of the United States, by the various Governments under the controul of Napoleon at the time of his power, those of the Swedish authorities in Pomerania, are the most shameless and inexcusable. For although the seizures there, as elsewhere were made at his requisition; they were actually released and discharged by his orders—but were still detained, and appropriated by the Swedish Officers themselves. Hughes has written, that he was informed from very respectable authority (Baron Rehausen) that according to the universal impression, the whole money proceeding from this pillage of Americans went in to the private pockets or purses of Count Engeström, the Minister of foreign Affairs; and of Baron Wettersted the Chancellor. There has been more shuffling and equivocation too by the Swedish Government, in the discussions upon these claims than by any of the other Governments upon claims of a similar character. Wettersted invariably admitted with Ecky the Justice of the claims, and the obligation of the Swedish Government to discharge them. They offered Ecky to pay him in Cannon or Articles for which he could have no use, and of which he could not dispose; but when Mr Russell came to present the claim with the sanction of this Government, they answered by false allegations which they knew to be false; and by denying their obligation to indemnify the sufferers which they had before, time after time recognized— I read to Ecky the Letter from Hughes which unfolds the tale so creditable to Count Engeström and Baron Wettersted; at which he was much astonished— He said however he should not yet despair of ultimately obtaining something; were it but cannon balls, lead, or
saltpetre— I took this day a survey of the chambers occupied for the use of the Department, in the new Building to which we have removed; and also of the Library. The Books and papers are all in great confusion; but Mr Colvin and Mr Young are endeavouring to reduce them to some order. Great inconvenience has hitherto been experienced for want of room; and as no single person has been responsible for the Books many of them are lost. There is now a spacious chamber allotted to the library; and it will be my duty to prescribe some regulations for the order of the Office— I wrote to the President and transmitted to him Letters and despatches received from Europe—

21. VI:30. Called at the Metropolis Bank, and gave A. Kerr the Cashier, a check to order upon the Branch Bank at Boston for the balance I have in deposit there. Mr Poinsett of South Carolina called at the Office with Mr Pleasonton, and Mr W. Jones of Philadelphia called at the house, while I was at the Office— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here in the Evening.

22. VI:30.Cardelli was here this morning, recovered from his indisposition, which was in a great measure hypocondriac. He is to come to-morrow Evening to give the first lesson of drawing to the children. I called at Davis’s Hotel to visit Mr Poinsett; but he was abroad— Captain Morris called at the Office to enquire for Instructions, for his Expedition— I examined the Papers which Captain Perry had, and which since his Death have been returned to the Navy Department; but found nothing requiring any further Instruction for Morris. I received a Letter from J. A. Smith, with a Statement of Account, not very intelligible; and the impression of a Seal, of which I had sent him last May a device to be engraved, and which I intend as a present to my Son John; having given one to George, before we came from England— George’s was the Crest of the Boylston arms—a Lion holding a Cross; and his Cypher G. W. A.— This Seal for John is a Ship, “fluctibus laborans,” and the Motto from Horace Lib. 1. Ode 14. “Fortiter Occupa Portum”; with the cypher J. A. beneath. My purpose is in giving a trinket to my Son, to give him at the same time a useful moral lesson, and an elegant classical allusion.

23. V:45. Wrote Letters to the Brokers, M’Ewen, Hale and Davidson at Philadelphia, and to Trueman Tyler, Cashier of the Planter’s Bank, Prince George’s County; both probably to little purpose; but I wish to get my private concerns in such a train before the Meeting of Congress that they may require little of my attention during the Session— I called at the Branch and Metropolis Banks; but could not get the order that I wanted upon Philadelphia. Mr T. Cooke of the War Office was at mine, and engaged to make some enquiries for me, concerning a house advertised for sale— I received a Letter from the President, enclosing one from Shaler to him, containing a confidential account of an unpleasant misunderstanding which has arisen between Commodore Stewart, the commander of our Squadron in the Mediterranean, and the Captains of all the ships he has with him. Decatur had spoken to me of this affair which has excited a strong public sensation, and which he says is attributable altogether to a half-lawyer, named Bourne who was employed as the Judge Advocate— The President directed me to shew Shaler’s Letter to the other members of the Administration, and thinks that Bourne ought to be immediately suspended and recalled. He also agrees in the opinion I had suggested to him, that it is advisable to propose to the French Minister Hyde de Neuville, to postpone his voyage to France, and to return and pass the Winter here. I wrote to de Neuville accordingly. Cardelli, this Evening gave the first lesson of drawing to Mary Hellen and Charles.

24. VI:15. Attended public worship at Mr M’Cormick’s Church. He read the Morning service for the 20th. Sunday after Trinity, and a Sermon from Psalm 150.6. “Let every thing that hath breath praise the Lord. Praise ye the Lord.” Since I have now resided at Washington, I have not regularly attended any Church— Partly because I have permitted the week to encroach too much upon the Sabbath, and have not been sufficiently attentive to the duties of the day, but chiefly because although the Churches here are numerous and diversified; not one of them is of the Independent Congregational Class to which I belong, the Church to which I was bred, and in
which I will die— And although I can frequent without scruple the church of any other sect of Christians, and join with cheerfulness in the social worship of all, without subscribing implicitly to the doctrines of any; yet here at Washington, none of the preachers has had an attraction powerful enough to draw me permanently to his Church. I have at last given the preference to Mr M’Cormick, of the Episcopal Church; and spoke to him last week for a pew— I this day however went with Charles into the first that I found empty. After Church I had a visit from General Parker, who told me that General Miller went from here, about a fortnight since; to repair to his Government of the Arkansaw Territory— Parker thinks he will not remain there, and gives a very unfavourable account of the Territory itself— My wife and the children spent the Evening at W. S. Smith’s, and I once more completed bringing up the arrears of this diary

25. VI:30.Mr Thomas Cooke called at my house this Morning, and reported concerning the business of which I had spoken to him on Saturday— A person, I know not whom, had already been to Dr Ewell, announcing himself as my agent; and entered into Negotiation with him for his house— This Circumstance should be a warning to me; and how many warnings have I, not even to think any thing, without taking for granted that it will be known, to those who are interested to know it. At the Office, Mr Crawford called and returned me the President’s Letter to Shaler andShaler’s to the President. He mentioned all the papers relating to the Mediterranean quarrel, which are at the Navy Department: and was of opinion that Bourne ought to be ordered home under arrest— Crawford sent me on Saturday an application from Antrobus, the British Chargé d’Affaires for the admission, free of duties of certain Silks imported by J. J. Astor from China, for Mr Bagot for his own use but just now arrived. Crawford desired my opinion whether it ought to be allowed— I told him I thought it should that a liberal indulgence of this privilege to foreign Ministers ought to be granted, so long as it was exercised bona fide, and there was no reason to suspect abuse— He agreed to this principle, observing that if Mr Bagot had taken definitive leave here, instead of going away on a leave of absence, there would be no doubt that the goods could not be admitted; but I remarked he might even in that case have claimed a permission to re-export them which would have come to the same thing— I told Crawford that Astor had written to me, when he sent out this ship offering to procure any thing that I might want in China; and my wife had sent also for some Silks— He said that Astor had made him the same offer; but he had only requested him in answer to procure for him some living tea-plants; which he thought might be cultivated in Louisiana. There has been some correspondence between a Dr. Rafinesque and Dr Mitchill about the cultivation of the tea-plant in this Country— Mr George Sullivan of Boston, and Mr Poinsett spent the Evening here— Sullivan has been to visit the President at Oak-hill; his Seat in Loudoun County—and returned this day— I made a change in the chimney of my writing chamber.

26. VI:15.Mr Josiah Meigs, the father of Mrs. Forsyth came yesterday to my Office to ask my advice, whether it would be expedient for her, to go to join her husband in Spain at present— I advised that she should wait till the Spring; as well because this is an unfavourable Season of the year, for a Lady with small children to cross the Atlantic, as because the state of our political relations with Spain is so precarious that it is quite possible by the time she could reach Madrid, her husband would be recalled— I assigned to Mr Meigs such reasons for my opinion, as quite convinced him it would be best for his daughter to remain here; and I informed him that if she should want money for her family expenditures, she should be supplied with it as Mr. Forsyth had requested— This morning I experienced the usual effect of the removal of immediate pressure for writing: relaxation of Industry— Writing slow; and without knowing precisely how, or being conscious of indolence; finding after a lapse of given time less; or rather almost nothing accomplished— I merely closed a Letter to T. H. Hubbard which was begun yesterday; and wrote the Journal of the day; yet it was past Noon before I left my house to go to the Office— Commodore Morris came to ask if any further Instructions were to be given to him upon his proposed expedition to Buenos-Ayres— Upon reading over all Perry’s papers, I observed
no necessity for new Instructions— I selected the papers to be delivered to him, and sent them to his lodgings. He had been yesterday to see the President at Oakhill, and said something to him about the compensation for the extra service— Perry was to have had besides his pay, at the rate of one thousand dollars a year, while residing on shore— Morris intimated to the President that this would be inadequate, and remarking that his habits were economical, proposed that his actual expenses should be paid. The President thought that something specific should be fixed, which would answer the same purpose— Morris proposed to take the opinion of Mr Poinsett, who was long at Buenos-Ayres, upon the necessary expenses of living there, to which I assented. General Parker brought me the papers relating to a Court Martial at West-Point, upon some disorderly conduct of certain Cadets there— The Court Martial decided that they had no jurisdiction, the Cadets not being in their opinion subject to the Articles of War— The case being referred back to the President he took the opinion of the Attorney General, which was that the Cadets were subject to the Articles of War— The Court-Martial were again assembled and adhered to their first opinion—and now the President refers all the papers to the members of the Administration, to consult them conjointly— William Lee came with a Letter to him from Jas Stackpole, and John Peck, now at Lexington Kentuckey, asking for copies of certain papers deposited in the Office, relating to the Yazoo claims— I desired Lee to answer that copies of papers in the office were given only upon application from judicial authorities— Mrs Brown’sson of Georgetown came to renew his solicitation for my aid to obtain him an appointment as a Clerk in any of the public offices. He said his Salary at the Bank of Columbia was reduced, & he was not even sure of keeping the place— I promised to serve him if it should be in my power. Cardelli gave the children this evening a second lesson of drawing. They passed the remainder of the Evening with my wife at W. S. Smith’s.

27. V: Two hours by Candle-light. I resumed the preparation of the Report upon weights and measures, by an abstract of the Statutes of the State of New York, transmitted by Governor Clinton. Called at the Metropolis Bank, and renewed a Note there.— Then upon Mr Anderson the Comptroller of the Treasury, concerning the settlement of my Accounts on Missions abroad from 1809 to 1817— There are several items unadjusted, and one of considerable amount, which is involved in great difficulty— I asked Mr Anderson for several papers, which he promised to have looked up, and to send me— At the office I had visits from Mr Nathan Levy and from Mr Cathcart, men who have occupied much of my time, with their concerns. There has been a two years negotiation with the Danish Government to get Mr Levy admitted as Vice-Consul, or commercial agent at the Island of St. Thomas. There is a promise now that he shall be admitted, of which I had notice given to him a few days since. He came now to ask a number of things, one of which at least was not very discreet. He said that in case of a War with Spain, and still more with England, there would be great numbers of distressed American Seamen; and considerable advances of money for them would be necessary— What was he to do, for reimbursement—as Bills upon this Country could not be negotiated— This was a barefaced trick, to hear what I should say, in relation to the prospects of Peace and War— I told him that when the case should occur it would be time enough to provide for it; and I was so displeased at the insidious nature and pertness of this question, that I treated Mr Levy in a frosty manner for which he will hate and traduce me— Mr Cathcart came again with his antediluvian claims upon the Government; claims which I have more than ten times told him I have no authority to allow but upon which he besieges me with perseverance stronger than Love, and with iteration for which Falstaff epithet to the word is its only suitable character— Cathcart puts me out of temper with him, and out of humour with myself. I finally promised him to make a report upon his claims to be ready at the first meeting of Congress— A task which I shall find it hard enough to accomplish— Received despatches and duplicates from J. Graham at Rio de Janeiro; and the rest of the Office hours were absorbed in reading the papers of the
Court Martial upon the Cadets at West-Point— Judge William Cranch of Alexandria came and dined with us; but went away immediately after dinner— His natural gravity of character seems to have almost turned to settled melancholy.

28. IV:15. The visitors at my Office, were Mr Kerr, Cashier of the Metropolis Bank, who came to ask me to divide into two, an order which I had given him upon the Branch Bank at Boston, which I did; Mr Homans of the Navy Department, to whom I communicated the President’s direction that Bourne, the half-lawyer judge Advocate in the Mediterranean, who has produced a breach between Commodore Stewart, and all the superior Officers of his Squadron, should be suspended and ordered home— Homans sent me all the papers relating to the affair which have been received at the Navy Department— But I had scarcely time to finish reading those of the West-Point Court Martial— Mr S. H. Smith too came and recommended to me a Mr Tastet, a Spaniard, who is here with a wife and children in want— Cardelli gave the children a lesson of drawing this Evening— I pursue, the Subject of weights and measures.

29. VI: I awoke as I found by striking my repeater at half past three this morning; which being too early an hour to rise, I returned to bed, and without much repose lay till six which is an hour too late. At the Office, Coll. Lane, and General Mason called— Lane’s object was to speak of the Capitol, and the new buildings for the public Offices. He asked me to go and view the Halls as they are now finished at the Capitol, and particularly the painting of the Cielings, of which he said he was himself no judge, and of which he wished to take my opinion. I asked him concerning the fire engines— He said he expected to receive them in a few days from Philadelphia— He told me that the owners of the temporary building in which the two houses of Congress have for several years held their Sessions were taking great pains and using much address to excite apprehensions in the members, that the walls of the new Halls would not be sufficiently dry for the Houses to occupy them— It was very ridiculous, but quite probable that they would succeed. General Mason came with a Letter from Niles, the Editor of the Register, recommending Mr Bland, for the appointment of District Judge in Maryland— It was to N. F. Williams and forwarded by him to Genl. Mason, who renewed and pressed again his own recommendation of Bland. He went over all the old ground, which I did not think it necessary to discuss; being very sure that Bland will be appointed. Mason glanced at his own situation, and said Mr Crawford had informed him they were endeavouring to trace something against him for his transactions with Mr Aguirre. He was a Cannon founder— He sold his Cannon to Mr Aguirre, as he sold them to any one else. Very possibly some of the Cannon of the privateers fitted out at Baltimore had been purchased him; and he had no doubt he had sold Cannon, on one and the same day to an Agent of the king of Spain, and an agent of the Patriots. He was at least impartial and there was no disguise in transactions which he had considered as being in the regular way of his business— He also repeated Bland’s insinuations against the Abbe Correa; charging him with having suborned witnesses to testify against Bland. He said Correa acted by other persons— To see him work you must look at three or four men off, from him; they were channels through which he operated, and they had given Sands money to testify against others— I observed that there could be no credit attached to Sands’s testimony, for his own story began by charging himself with perjury. I was not disposed to defend the conduct of the Spanish or Portuguese Ministers. But their official duty was to defend the property of their Countrymen; although the facts were perfectly notorious, it was difficult to prove them; all who could be witnesses, being participators of the crime: and as to the fact of money’s being given to a witness; that would not be conclusive evidence of subornation— If in his zeal for the service of his Country, Mr Correa, had transcended the line of his obligations to this, and had wronged any individual, complaint against him
might be received, and addressed to his own Government; but as to his exertions to save or to redeem the property of Portuguese Merchants, robbed by the Baltimore piratical privateers, I considered it as so vigorously his duty to use them, that without approving any departure from the straight courses, I should look with indulgence even upon indiscretions in the discharge of his duty— The General was as usual very courtly, and pleasant in his deportment— I took home with me the Maryland Laws to take from them an abstract of the Statutes upon Weights and Measures; but instead of that I got involved, in certain arithmetical calculations which absorbed the whole Evening— Cardelli gave a lesson of drawing to the children— Received a satisfactory answer from M’Ewen, Hale and Davidson.

30. V: The calculations seized hold of me again this Morning, and consumed two or three hours of my time; so that I had barely enough left to make the abstract from the Maryland Laws which I had intended. At the Office I called upon Pleasonton who was not at his but afterwards came to me— He furnished me two or three papers, which I wanted for the further elucidation of my public accounts on the foreign Missions. He also gave me some papers relating to Mr Cathcart’s claim— Mr Thierry, the French Charge d’Affaires called, and brought me a Letter from Mr Hyde de Neuville the Minister; mentioning that on receipt of my Letter he had immediately concluded, although he was just going on board the vessel in which he had engaged his passage for France, to have his baggage relanded, and come back to Washington. Thierry said this was quite unexpected to him—and he looked as if it did not exactly suit him to be shorn of his honours and emoluments as Charge d’Affaires— I could not find it in my heart to congratulate him upon Mr. de Neuville’s return— Mr Antrobus the British Charge d’Affaires, came and said he had heard that I had received information of Mr Bagot’s having been appointed Ambassador to Russia; and enquired if it was so. I said Lord Castlereagh had told Mr Rush that the appointment of Mr Bagot to Russia, though not actually made had been determined upon in the Cabinet— Antrobus said he was expecting his despatches by the Packet; which was longer coming from Halifax to New-York than it had been from Falmouth to Halifax— He asked also when the President was expected to return to the City— He said he had a Letter from the Prince Regent to present— I told him the President was to come next Tuesday— The children dined at W. S. Smith’s, and my wife spent the Evening there. There was a fire this Evening at the Navy yard— Two or three small frame houses— I went out to go to it; but before I reached the place it was subdued— I met the people returning from it, and came back myself.— Evening engaged on my Journal.

31. VI: Attended again at Mr M’Cormick’s Church, and heard him read Prayers for the 21st. Sunday after Trinity, and preach from 1. Corinthians 11.29. [“]For he that eateth and drinketh unworthily, eateth and drinketh damnation to himself, not discerning the Lord’s body.” It was a Sermon preparatory to the communion which he gave notice would be administered next Sunday, when as usual on that occasion a collection would be made. It was a very earnest exhortation to join in the communion; which most of the Christian Churches consider as a duty of the most indispensable obligation— Our Independents, especially the Unitarians, are more indifferent about it than any others; for I do not recollect having ever heard from one of their pulpits a recommendation of it. They are not discerning of the Lord’s body.— As I was returning home I met Coll. Lane, with whom I went and viewed the Halls of the Senate and House of Representatives at the Capitol— They are yet both unfinished; and there will barely be time to have them finished before the Meeting of Congress— They are both too small; but particularly the Senate chamber— The Hall of the House of Representatives will be magnificent, but not convenient, nor in a good taste. Lane says the Stone of which the Capitol is built is too soft, and before many years will crumble into sand— We had evening visits successively from Mr Bailey and from Dr Thornton—the latter of whom was amusing.

Day. I rise irregularly from four to seven O’Clock in the Morning—making an average of about half past five— An irregularity which notwithstanding all the pains I have taken to correct it, still continues— I believe it owing to a complaint with which I am afflicted, which disturbs my repose in the Night, and makes my sleep irregular— On rising, I kindle the fire, in the chamber to which my cabinet is removed, and write till between 8 and 9 when we breakfast, that the children may go betimes to school— After breakfast a cursory glance at the newspapers, and occasional family concerns occupy me till near noon when I repair to my Office— Thence I return home at four P.M— Write in my chamber till half past five when we dine— Allowing for this an hour and a half I then pass from seven till ten of the Evening in my chamber, writing, except when interrupted by visitors, which happens from two to three times a week— Early rising and restless nights make me a dull and drowsy Evening companion— The only remedy for which, extreme temperance, not only of eating, but of drinking I do not always observe— Drowsiness is the first consequence of repletion. I waste as usual much of my time upon trifles. I suppose it irradicable from my character— I would if possible devote every moment of my time to useful employment, but my nature shrinks from the perfection of the theory.
